Idiom (Tetum): Bee tun hodi halakon kabun boot
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To ease a heavy burden or relieve strong emotions
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To find relief or feel lighter
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from rural life; water calming the land after floods
First Example Sentence: Bainhira nia konta problema hotu, bee tun hodi halakon kabun boot.
Second Example Sentence: Ha'u sente bee tun hodi halakon kabun boot depois de koalia ho alin.
Third Example Sentence: Nia hanorin katak koalia bele hanesan bee tun hodi halakon kabun boot.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone who is charming but elusive
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Folklore image of a mystical bird flying at night
First Example Sentence: Nia hanesan manu fulan, ema hotu haree maibé la bele kaer.
Second Example Sentence: Istória hakerek nia hanesan manu fulan iha kalan.
Third Example Sentence: Sira dehan nia manu fulan tanba laos fasiak hatene.

Idiom (Tetum): Feto boot hanesan rai-nain iha uma
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A respected woman is the foundation of the household
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A woman plays an important role in the family
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Customary law (lisan) emphasizing women’s roles in the household
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tetum): /fetu boːt hanesan rai nain iha uma/
First Example Sentence: Feto boot hanesan rai-nain iha uma, tanba nia fo dalan ba labarik sira.
Second Example Sentence: Kultura Timor sempre dehan feto boot hanesan rai-nain iha uma.
Third Example Sentence: Nia mos prova katak feto boot hanesan rai-nain iha uma.

Idiom (Tetum): Asaun ida mak hatudu ema nia moris-loron
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You are known by what you do
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional teachings emphasizing deeds over words
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tetum): /asaun ida mak hatudu ema nia moɾis loɾon/
First Example Sentence: Asaun ida mak hatudu ema nia moris-loron, laos liafuan.
Second Example Sentence: Ha'u hanoin katak asaun ida mak hatudu ema nia moris-loron.
Third Example Sentence: Professór hatete tanba asaun ida mak hatudu ema nia moris-loron.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Sacred matters must be kept pure and respected
First Example Sentence: Lulik hanesan laran mutin, tenki respeita hela.
Second Example Sentence: Sira hatete lulik hanesan laran mutin no la bele tokar.
Third Example Sentence: Avó koalia kona-ba lulik hanesan laran mutin.

Idiom (Tetum): Dalan ida ne'e hanesan dalan tolu
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: The situation is uncertain or unpredictable
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from confusing crossroads in rural roads
First Example Sentence: Politika iha Timor-Leste dalan ida ne'e hanesan dalan tolu.
Second Example Sentence: Situasaun sira dala mak hanesan dalan ida ne'e hanesan dalan tolu.
Third Example Sentence: Ha'u senti ne'e hanesan dalan ida ne'e hanesan dalan tolu.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One must not forget their cultural roots
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects resistance to colonial erasure of identity
First Example Sentence: Avó hatete tanba la bele haluha kultura.
Second Example Sentence: Eskola sempre fo hatene katak la bele haluha kultura.
Third Example Sentence: Ha'u koalia ho labarik kona-ba la bele haluha kultura.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Good deeds will return to you
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional belief in reciprocity and balance
First Example Sentence: Ha'u ajuda nia tanba ha'u hatene buat di'ak sei fila mai.
Second Example Sentence: Sira hanorin katak buat di'ak sei fila mai.
Third Example Sentence: Buat di'ak sei fila mai se ita halo ho sincero.

Idiom (Tetum): Kabun boot la bele iha ai-laran ki'ik
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A big problem cannot be solved with small means
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agricultural imagery: large stomach cannot be filled by tiny fruit
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Tetum): /kabun boːt la bele iha ai laɾan kiʔik/
First Example Sentence: Kabun boot la bele iha ai-laran ki'ik, hanesan problema governu.
Second Example Sentence: Ekonomia mos hatudu kabun boot la bele iha ai-laran ki'ik.
Third Example Sentence: Ha'u hanoin problema ne'e kabun boot la bele iha ai-laran ki'ik.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To act naively or without caution
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to buying water as if it were pure rice; seen as foolishness
First Example Sentence: Nia sosa bee ho kabun mutin bainhira nia entrega osan la hatene.
Second Example Sentence: Labarik ida halo hanesan sosa bee ho kabun mutin.
Third Example Sentence: Ha'u hanorin katak la bele sosa bee ho kabun mutin.
